Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award,the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Barbara Wyslouzil at Ohio State University to pursue an integrated experimental and molecular modeling program exploring the physics of freezing. This includes determining the limits to which liquids can be supercooled, the transformation kinetics, and the structure of the emerging solid phase. The focus is on short chain-like molecules, i.e. n-alkanes and n-alcohols with less than 12 carbons, confined in nanodroplets. These chain molecules are the building blocks of materials as diverse as lipids, surfactants, and polymers. Freezing is a fundamental physical process that plays a central role in both industry and nature, such as in atmospheric aerosols. The freezing transitions will be quantitatively investigated with extremely well characterized samples under conditions that are far from equilibrium, and a powerful set of experimental tools probes conditions very close to the still idealized requirements of molecular simulations. Prof. Wyslouzil will also engage with high school students in her research and conduct public outreach in collaboration with the Steam Factory, an initiative at her institution to promote interdisciplinary collaboration across Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Math.

Prof. Wyslouzil and her research group will pursue the following specific experimental objectives: (1) measure liquid to solid nucleation rates as nanodroplets freeze, (2) explore the role of molecular structure on the relative importance of surface versus bulk freezing, and (3) further develop X-ray scattering techniques to follow this transformation directly. The objectives of the molecular modeling work are to (1) understand the driving force for surface freezing in chain-like molecules, and (2) calculate liquid-solid nucleation rates to compare directly to the measured values. Supersonic nozzle flows are to generate liquid droplets in highly non-equilibrium states with static pressure measurements to characterize the flow, spatially resolved small and wide angle X-ray scattering (SAXS/WAXS) to characterize the aerosol, and infrared spectroscopy to quantify the distribution of the condensable fraction among the vapor, liquid and solid states. Efforts to develop single nanodroplet/nanocrystal X-ray diffraction measurements to measure the structure of freezing clusters on a particle-by-particle basis using free electron lasers are to be extended. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are to directly test competing theories of surface freezing, and develop molecular level insight into homogeneous liquid-solid nucleation using available interaction potentials for both n-alcohols and n-alkanes at the united atom or all-atom level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freezing, or crystallization, plays a critical role in a large number of industries including semiconductor processing, pharmaceutical production and purification, and metallurgy. In the atmosphere a cloud's radiative properties and the chemistry that can take place within it both depend on whether the cloud consists of water droplets, ice particles or a mixture of both. To develop accurate models of industrial processes, atmospheric chemistry and global climate it is important to be able to predict the conditions required to initiate freezing, the rate at which freezing occurs, and the role free surfaces play in freezing.

Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of our proposed research was to explore the physics of freezing, including the limits to which liquids can be supercooled, the transformation path and kinetics, and the structure of the emerging solid phase. Questions of specific interest include: (1) How do the degree of supercooling and the nucleation kinetics vary with sample volume and cooling rate? (2) How does molecular structure affect freezing - especially for highly asymmetric molecules? (3) Can we observe and characterize freezing on the surface of droplets as compared to bulk freezing? (4) Are molecular dynamics (MD) simulations using approximate models able to capture the important physics and clarify the mechanism that drives surface freezing?

Experiments and theory largely focused short chain linear alkanes because these molecules are the building blocks of materials as diverse as lipids, surfactants, and polymers. Furthermore, it is easy to systematically vary the chain length and investigate how this parameter affects the ability of alkanes to self-assemble and form layered structures. We also conducted experiments with water because this molecule is in many ways the opposite of the oily alkanes. In our experiments with alkanes ranging from n-hexane to n-decane, it was easy to supercool liquid nanodroplets far below the normal melting point and observe freezing by all of our analytical methods. In contrast, pentane never froze on the timescale of our experiments. The kinetics of freezing suggested that for many of these materials freezing proceeded from the outside in, i.e. the surface organized first before the rest of the droplet froze. Extensive Molecular Dynamics simulations led to a deeper understanding of the delicate balance between enthalpic and entropic driving forces that enable this behavior.  In contrast, when water droplets froze, the kinetics were consistent with freezing starting randomly throughout the droplet. The water did not however freeze to the normal hexagonal form of ice. Rather it appears to form a structure of interleaved hexagonal and cubic layers.

In addition to quantifying the kinetics of freezing, we were also able to measure the vapor-liquid nucleation rates of the alkanes. Monte Carlo simulations using standard force fields were able to capture the observed behavior remarkably well.

 Broader Impact

Our work developed novel applications of small angle scattering, spectroscopy, and molecular modeling techniques that address fundamental problems in aerosol science. The approach provides a new way to quantitatively investigate the freezing transitions with extremely clean samples under conditions that are far from equilibrium, and a powerful set of experimental tools that probe conditions very close to the still idealized requirements of simulations.
